repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Forest Resources Management,
            Silk Development Pilot, and Agricultural Services Innovation
            & Reform Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This assessment generally concurred with
            the completion report ratings for the three projects, with
            the following exceptions: the institutional development
            impact was rated as substantial for all projects, for the
            Silk Development Pilot Project, the PPAR found the outcome
            to be moderately satisfactory; and for the Agricultural
            Services Innovation and Reform Project the PPAR found the
            outcome to be moderately satisfactory and the Bank's
            performance to be satisfactory.  All three projects
            contributed to pro-poor growth, though to varying degrees.
            Four specific lessons regarding the pro-poor growth
            challenge, and a final lesson related to the Bank's
            strategy for Bangladesh's rural sector have emerged
            from this review: a) dedicated focus on enhancing
            productivity pays off; b) socially inclusive rural
            development need not constrain rapid agricultural growth; c)
            government-civil society partnerships can enable gains in
            development capacity, both for social inclusion and for
            agricultural growth; d) to enhance benefits for women and
            the poor, project formulation needs the systematic
            integration of measures to achieve this; and e) the
            Bank's rural project portfolio in Bangladesh would
            merit scaling-up, prioritizing, a longer-term program
            approach, and a better strategic framework.

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project are as
            follows: the project outcome is satisfactory, the
            project's sustainability is likely, the institutional
            development impact is modest, and the Bank and Borrower
            performance are both satisfactory. Several key lessons were
            learnt from the implementation of this pilot project in
            terms of impact of the global market on the competitiveness
            of silk sub-sector, institutional reforms, women's
            entrepreneurship development, merits of pilot project and
            institutional framework for innovative projects. Bangladesh
            has good potential for sericulture and cocoon processing and
            can compete in a world market where the playing field is
            level and not dominated by China, as it is now. Sericulture
            can provide an attractive income for the rural poor, but not
            necessarily for those who have no access to some land, or
            modest amount of finance (own equity or credit) needed to
            start the operations. Sericulture as an activity depends on
            efficient downstream processing of cocoons and weaving, and
            will only be successful if there is vertical integration of
            all stages of the production chain. Initiating fundamental
            institutional reforms in a deeply entrenched bureaucratic
            structure is difficult and time consuming and should not be
            under-estimated at project design stage. Pilot projects, if
            well designed and supervised project, can be very successful
            in demonstrating new technologies and in supporting
            politically sensitive institutional reforms--their
            particular strength being an ability to focus on important
            key details rather than concerns about rates of progress or
            disbursement. Not-for-profit Foundations can provide the
            essential support services representing the interests of a
            range of stakeholders from small scale producers through to
            manufactures. However, there are problems in securing
            adequate autonomy for foundations initially supported with
            government funds, and in attracting capable managers from
            the private sector.

5081280.trustfund:
TF034846-BANGLADESH - SILK DEVELOPMENT
            PILOT PROJECT,TF040698-BANGLADESH: SILK DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF029466-PHRD-SILK DEVLEOPMENT PROJ.(BANK-EXEC.),TF029556-PHRD-SILK DEV. PROJ. (RECIPIENT-EXEC.),TF033705-BANGLADESH - AGRICULTURE
5081280.majtheme: Public sector governance,Rural development,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Silk Development Project, the first
            phase of a long-term program to help increase the incomes of
            small-scale silk producers, mostly poor women, introduces
            improved technology and creates institutional and policy
            improvements to address the constraints that affect silk
            development in Bangladesh. The project is composed of four
            components. The policy reform and institutional development
            component comprises five sub-components: 1) further
            deregulating the silk industry; restructuring the Bangladesh
            Sericulture Board (BSB) and its Research and Training
            Institute (BSRTI); 2) establishing the Silk Foundation (SF);
            3) promoting associations of producers of cocoons and raw
            silk; and 4) providing technical assistance to the Ministry
            of Textiles (MOT). The productivity enhancement and research
            component consists of investments aimed at improving sector
            performance and enhancing technology. This component
            comprises sub-components to develop research capacity to
            improve yields, productivity, and income; to establish,
            staff, and operate germplasm maintenance centers; to develop
            and lease grainages (hatcheries); and to support a pilot
            program to determine the country's potential
            competitive advantage for producing high quality bivoltine
            raw silk. The third component, technology dissemination,
            develops the training capacity of BSRTI; sets up field
            training centers for chawki rearers, silkworm rearers, and
            reelers; funds the salaries of extension staff and provides
            technical assistance; and disseminates information about
            chawki rearing technology (which improves the quality of
            eggs and the rearing process). The fourth component, product
            development and market promotion, funds experts and training
            to produce fashion designs for trade shows, and finances
            project monitoring and evaluation.
